inscription: {Bunsei 9 nen Hei jutsu satsuki Sakurada Tansai 桜田澹斎 gakun no shoku ni o-jite sha su} (Bunsei 9 in the fifth month / Painted as requested by Sakurada Tansai's request.)
markings: L center: 谷文晁印 {Tani Bunchhō no in}
medium: Hanging scroll, ink and color on silk
text: Over the centuries, wind and waves have formed the rocks of Matsushima into spectacular shapes. In the upper right hand corner is Zaimoku Island with its impressive stone arch that used to be one of the most famous sightseeing spots in Matsushima until the arch collapsed during an earthquake in 1969. Tani Bunchō, one of the most prolific painters in Edo art circles, traveled to Matsushima at least four times. Bunchō uses the “blue-and-green-style, ” reminiscent of Chinese painting during the Tang Dynasty (618–907), to render the pine islands.
title: Matsushima
